aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident in Orlando, Florida
The accident occurred in Orlando, Florida.
The accident occurred on June 29, 2014, at 15:35 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Cessna 172S.
The defining event was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Instructional.
The accident number was ERA14CA317.
The aircraft registration was N775SP.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The accident resulted in 2 minor injuries.
The flight instructor completed an approximate 1 hour flight with his student pilot.
The flight instructor and student pilot landed uneventfully.
After landing, the airplane had a long taxi to return to the fixed based operator.
During the taxi, a thunderstorm moved into the area.
The wind increased during the taxi.
The strong wind caused the airplane to weathervane violently in one direction.
The wind lifted the airplane.
The wind flipped the airplane over.
The airplane came to rest inverted on the taxiway.
There were no preimpact mechanical malfunctions with the airplane.
A Federal Aviation Administration inspector examined the airplane.
The examination revealed damage to the fuselage.
The examination revealed damage to the wings.
The examination revealed damage to the rudder.
The examination revealed damage to the horizontal stabilizer.
The recorded wind at the airport at the time of the accident was from 120 degrees at 10 knots.
The recorded wind was gusting to 31 knots.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the flight instructor's failure to maintain control while taxiing in a strong gusty wind.
The findings included issues with instructor/check pilot aircraft control.
The findings included aircraft not attained/maintained.
The findings included gusts as an environmental issue affecting operation.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Orlando, Florida

## Date & Time: 
June 29, 2014, 15:35 Local

## Aircraft:
Cessna 172S

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Instructional

## Accident Number:
ERA14CA317

## Registration:
N775SP

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 Minor

## Analysis

The flight instructor reported that he had completed an approximate 1 hour flight with his student pilot and they landed uneventfully. After landing, the airplane had a long taxi to return to the fixed based operator. During the taxi, a thunderstorm moved into the area and the wind increased. The strong wind caused the airplane to weathervane violently in one direction. The wind then lifted the airplane, flipped it over, and it came to rest inverted on the taxiway. The pilot added that there were no preimpact mechanical malfunctions with the airplane. Examination of the airplane by a Federal Aviation Administration inspector revealed damage to the fuselage, wings, rudder, and horizontal stabilizer. The recorded wind at the airport at the time of the accident was from 120 degrees at 10 knots, gusting to 31 knots.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:
The flight instructor's failure to maintain control while taxiing in a strong gusty wind.

## Findings

| | |
|-|-|
| Personnel issues | Aircraft control - Instructor/check pilot |
| Aircraft (general) | Not attained/maintained |
| Environmental issues | Gusts - Effect on operation |

---
